description: The conservative prime minister received a strong endorsement from voters, but the radical right-wing Jobbik party also gained strength.
title: Viktor Orban Wins a Second Term in Hungary
title_page: Viktor Orban Wins a Second Term in Hungary - The New York Times
maintext:
BUDAPEST — Voters in Hungary have re-elected Viktor Orban and his conservative political alliance in parliamentary elections, according to preliminary election results released on Monday.
The early vote count showed that Mr. Orban’s Fidesz party and a small conservative ally would keep a two-thirds majority, with 133 seats in the country’s 199-member Parliament.
A leftist alliance led by the socialist Attila Mesterhazy is expected to control 38 seats.
The vote, held Sunday, showed increasing support for the radical right Jobbik party, which won just more than 20 percent of the vote on national party lists, 4 percentage points higher than in 2010, and was expected to have 23 seats in Parliament.
With more than 98 percent of the votes counted, there was little room for change on Monday, although final results were expected later in the week.
